There is no limit to the hyperbole and plain lies that advertising will tell us. Ignoring the ridiculous “We live in your world” (which I bet sounded great to some ANZ executive in their marketing boardroom), how are ANZ making banking simpler? How can banking be any simpler? It’s a safe place to store your money, you gain modest interest on the account, you withdraw and pay for things from the account, you pay some fees for the convenience. That’s it. The explanation of banking as far as customers are concerned is not much longer than the billboard telling us how simple ANZ is making it.

For some reason this billboard reminds me of all those wireless broadband commercials that advertise a huge 2GB or a massive 500MB of data each month. How are they legally even able to describe it as that?

§ Jan 26th, 2010

Whole Foods Offers Discount Based On BMI →

Along with blood pressure, smoker or non-smoker and cholesterol levels. This is completely insane. As suggested in the comments a much better idea would be to provide no discount at all on unhealthy products and a steeper discount on healthy food for all employees. There’s nothing to be gained by making unhealthy people pay more for good food, extremely unhealthy food (fast food, etc.) is already much cheaper.

§ Jan 26th, 2010

But while Apple may be acting spitefully, they’re not spiting themselves. The iPhone’s lack of Flash has not hurt it one bit.

John Gruber in Apple, Adobe and Flash. This is what the entire Flash on the iPhone “debate” boils down to, those in the Flash camp say the iPhone has to support Flash, why? iPhones have been selling like hotcakes for two and a half years. Even if there’s people not buying the iPhone because of its lack of Flash (which I don’t believe there is) who cares? They’re selling millions of them.

Sidenote: Great to read a Gruber piece about the Mac and computers, even if shared with the iPhone.

§ Jan 26th, 2010

The way I see it, meat is the epitome of processed foods. Thousands of litres of water, fertiliser and months producing grain and produce that’s processed into feed for animals. Thousands more of litres of water, tons of grain and produce fed to cattle over their entire lifespan. Years after the process began the meat is processed into little packages ready to be transported to your supermarket.

We can eat what cattle eat, why not cut out the middle man animal?

§ Jan 24th, 2010

I have no interest in cooking or the preparation of food but I appreciate Salt & Fat for its lovely, crisp design.

§ Jan 24th, 2010

An Observation

While there’s in depth analysis of every Android/HTC/Google/Palm hardware or software development however minor, Windows 7 has been released seemingly without fanfare, inspection or even acknowledgement.

§ Jan 24th, 2010

Clients From Hell was one of those blogs that started out so great I read back through every post from their relatively short archive.

But since experiencing the sweet high of tumblarity Clients From Hell has succumbed to the post-as-much-as-you-can-regardless-of-quality trap that the Tumblr ecosystem fosters. Now it’s less clients from hell, more clients that are a little dumb, which is entertaining in itself but in a funniest home videos rather than stand up comedian way.

§ Jan 22nd, 2010

Until recently the only thing Flash has ever been good for is video playback online. HTML5’s introduction of the <video> element and browser’s support for it is rendering Flash totally obsolete to the joy of everyone outside Adobe.

I’ve been using ClickToFlash to serve me H264 video via <video> at YouTube for a while now. The experience is simply better. I’ve never used a custom Flash video player that didn’t suck and that’s excluding the way Flash churns through processor speed often kicking the fans into maximum RPM.

It’s fantastic to see YouTube and Vimeo both offering official (albeit testing) means to use HTML5 <video> over their Flash players. Before long I’ll be able to replace ClickToFlash with an uninstall of Flash Player altogether.

§ Jan 22nd, 2010

Having recently invested in a Nikon D90 and being in the middle of a small holiday there’s a thick stream of photos dropping into the Flickr account I’ve paid for and used on and off for almost 5 years.

There’s a lot to love about Flickr but again the antiquated 5 year old design and slow navigation is frustrating me. I upload huge files out of Aperture yet there’s no way to directly browse between photos at anything larger than 500px wide. Even that is an excruciatingly slow process with a full, heavy page reload required for each image.

Facebook, who don’t even store high resolution versions of images, have a much larger default browsing size and lighting fast navigation via keyboard and mouse.

I Hardly Know Her tries to address the issues but falls short with no way to force set views to show a larger size by default and omitting the title and caption, even from the meta data shown on mouse over. I’m all for the hiding by default but why omit the title and caption while including stuff like the aperture and shutter speed? Technical details few care about and remain a click away for those that do.

§ Jan 21st, 2010

Yesterday I completed the ride I was raising money for these past months. Six hours on the bike, 164km travelled, 1,700m climbed and 6,800 calories burned through some beautiful Australian wine country.

As a whole everyone participating in the ride raised $1.1 million to fund research into a cure for Type 1 diabetes, a great result.

The Tablet

Despite analysis finally coming from some respectable sources I’m having trouble getting enthusiastic or even interested in the mythical Apple Tablet.

Even the most extreme and unlikely predictions don’t appeal to me. Until proved wrong by an actual product I agree with Steve Jobs alleged dismissal of tablet computers: “What are these things good for besides surfing the Web on the toilet?”

§ Jan 3rd, 2010

Christmas Presents

This year I managed to land a huge amount of presents, most of them books. Despite my excitement about reading them I can’t help but feel that acquiring new books in 2009 is like building a fantastic HD-DVD library. The fact remains that books are simply the best way to read text. Although I haven’t tried a Kindle, I’d love it to prove even better.

Here’s a complete list of my haul:

  • Every Second Counts by Lance Armstrong
  • More Information Than You Require by John Hodgman
  • Areas of my Expertise by John Hodgman
  • Infinite Jest by David Foster Wallace
  • Emergency: This Book Will Save Your Life by Neil Strauss
  • Our Choice by Al Gore
  • The Camel Club by David Baldacci
  • The Story of Danny Dunn by Bryce Courtenay
  • Sophia Grantham by Barry Allan (my uncle)
  • Black Sheep and Gold Diggers by Barry Allan
  • The Chaser Annual 2009
  • Electrolux dust buster
  • Halo 3 ODST
  • Tour de France Greats DVD
  • Money tree, the non-magical plant
  • Island Spa Yankee Candle, which I’m burning right now and is the most amazing smelling thing.
  • Apple Wireless Keyboard
  • Pair of casual shorts
  • Party Ice Bucket
  • RSPCA calendar

My list of things I want to buy has taken a serious hit, I’m very lucky.

§ Dec 24th, 2009

§ Dec 23rd, 2009

I love Andre Torrez’s new year’s resolution idea:

So then it hit me: what if I only listened to music released in 2010? Okay.

As much as the thought of not listening to my favourite music for a year sucks, my entire library feels stale. Despite the magic of last.fm and iTunes Genius I struggle to find new music I like.

The idea of forcing yourself to actively search for new things to like really appeals to me. It’s too easy to get stuck in a comfortable bubble, endeavours like this push you out.

As it stands I’m over the moon when I hear a favourite song that I haven’t personally cued up. I imagine this effect would be amplified many times over when you haven’t heard any of your old favourites in months. I’d get excited again with the anticipation of a new realise from a favourite band. At the end of it all you’ve got a brand new set of artists you enjoy and songs you’d listened to over 100 times in the preceding years would feel fresh again. It’s a fantastic idea.

I make a point of only making a single resolution each year. I’ve got a week and a bit to think about whether this’ll be it.

§ Dec 22nd, 2009

Asking for Money

Every week I listen to This American Life plead for donations from its hundreds of thousands of podcast listeners. They remind us that producing and getting the show out to so many people is very expensive and they need donations to survive. If you enjoy the show, donate, they say.

It seems to me that there is a very simple answer to what seems to be an increasingly dire financial situation This American Life has found themselves in: charge for the podcast.

When I first discovered the show I couldn’t get enough. The only way to get more than one episode a week was to use the crappy flash player on their website or buy episodes as audio books from iTunes for $2 a piece. I bought at least 20 episodes when the alternatives were a totally free, mildly inconvenient player or simply waiting.

Charge for it. Rather than plead with people to support something they love, force them to. Even if they lost 80% of their podcast listeners, the still huge amount of remaining listeners will continue to enjoy the show (without the begging) and This American Life becomes financially secure.

But of course this is coming from a country which is perfectly comfortable in its complicated, equivocal system of tipping to support service industry staff rather than simply charging more and paying them more.

§ Dec 21st, 2009

PayPal Horror Story →

From every angle PayPal sucks. Yet, this story included, it remains the most viable option for accepting payment online. This is a sad state of affairs. I resent every second I’ve ever spent using PayPal’s unbelievably bad, fragmented developer documentation because even the best integration sucks for users and sucks for sellers.

There needs to be a PayPal exodus. Never again will I implement even the most inconsequential PayPal integration and neither should you.

Via Daring Fireball.
